description.narrative: The Mekong River and its Lower Basin fisheries sustain the livelihoods of more than 60 million people. Therefore, the governance ofwater resources is of critical importance. Decisions on how water resources are shared and managed influence the livelihoods of alland in particular the most disadvantaged and their food security. Since 2012, WWF-Laos, in partnership with the Lao fisheries authorities, has been running a project endeavouring for the sustainable co-management of aquatic resources in Siphandone, one of the most spectacular and biologically diverse wetland areas in Greater Mekong region. The project focuses on 30 villages in and around the braided Mekong River in Champassak Province. Thirty-seven fish conservation zones (FCZs, i.e. protected areas of rivers where fishing is prohibited) have been established in Khong and Mounlapamok districts. The communities are central in the set-up and management of the FCZs, which, along with community-managed patrols, help to protect the spawning areas and habitat of many species of fish. The project promotes the application of the 2009 Fisheries Law, which mandates villages to manage their natural aquatic resources in cooperation with district authorities. The FCZs are managed by Fisheries Management Committees (FMCs), in which women are mandated toparticipate. In total, almost 198 hectares of river is protected in the FCZs of Siphandone, replenishing natural fish stocks and hence enhancing the livelihood opportunities of local communities. To that end, WWF, in partnership with the Department of Livestock and Fisheries (DLF) and its local offices, has also trained people to improve livestock management practices, vaccinate cattle and poultry efficiently, and improve crop cultivation techniques. All of these activities grow villagers# ability to ensure food security and diversified incomes that take pressure off the river system. Through its Green Schools programme, the project raises youth environmental awareness in order to convey these newly learnedsustainable practices into the future. The programme runs in five schools in two districts engaging over 700 students. Learning about the value and importance of the aquatic environment, ways to sustainably use it, and understanding wider conservation anddevelopment issues that impact Laos, contributes to producing local long-term stewards of the environment. The activities proposed here will scale-up the leadership and impact of women participation in fisheries management by offering them a number of additional skills and means of participation which will enhance the quality of their engagement (especially within the FMCs) and by raising communities awareness about their vital role in natural resources management. The proposed project will work in Khong district of Champassak Province, in 3 villages: Ban Hangsadam, Ban Donekhone and Ban Houasadam

mailing-address.narrative: PO box 30919, 2500 GX The Hague, The Netherlands
